And take the golden fleece:
• Medea goes to Pelias and tricks his daughters into slicing him up.
• Jason wants to be with Medea, but she eventually kills her own children.
• Hercules (also known as Heracles) is considered the best of the demigods and is well-liked by the Greeks because of his strength.
• Zeus starts a war to obtain Amphitryon, disguising himself as Amphitryon and fathering a child with Alcmene.
• Hercules has to perform 12 labors as punishment for killing his family in a fit of madness.
• The labors are designed to kill, humiliate, and exhaust Hercules.
• Hercules completes all 12 labors and earns forgiveness for his guilt.
• Deianeria is being attacked by a centaur named Nessus and Hercules kills him with a poison arrow.
• Nessus gives Deianeria a love potion before he dies, causing Hercules to fall in love with her.
• Rumors spread that Hercules is seeing other women, and Deianeria sends the love potion which turns out to be acid. This causes Hercules to experience immense pain as he thinks his wife hates him.
Now, take all the notes you corrected previously and make terms with definitions.

Medea: A character in Greek mythology who tricks the daughters of Pelias and kills the old goat after slicing him up.

Jason: A character in Greek mythology who seeks to be with Medea, but is ultimately the villain.

Hercules (also known as Herakles): The best of the demigods, known for his strength and often considered to be both strong and somewhat foolish.

Amphitryon: A general in Greek mythology and father of Alcides.

Zeus: The king of the gods in Greek mythology who starts a war to get Amphitryon.

Alcmene: The mother of Hercules and the target of jealousy from Hera.

Iphicles (also known as Amphitryon): The son of Amphitryon and Alcmene, and half-brother to Hercules.

Thespian: A music teacher who is killed by Alcides when learning music.

Minvans: A group of people in Greek mythology who are defeated by Alcides in a war.

Alcides (also known as Heracles): The son of Amphitryon and Alcmene, known for his great strength and as the subject of the Twelve Labors.

Megara: The wife of Alcides who is killed by him in a fit of madness.

Theseus: A character in Greek mythology who stops Alcides from killing himself.

Eurystheus: A king who Hercules must perform the Twelve Labors for in order to atone for his guilt.

Hera: The queen of the gods in Greek mythology and the source of jealousy towards Alcmene and her son Hercules.

Deianira: The wife of Hercules who mistakenly poisons him with a love potion.

Nessus: A centaur who attacks Deianira and is killed by Hercules with a hydra poison arrow.
somewhere in there it says "sidestory" it was something about the origin of Alcides

Alcides Side Story:

Alcides, also known as Hercules, was the son of Zeus and Alcmene. Hera, who was jealous of Alcmene, attempted to kill Hercules as a baby. Athena and Hera found Hercules and attempted to breastfeed him, but Hercules bit down on Hera's breast and she realized he was Zeus's son.

Hera wanted to kill Hercules after learning he was Zeus's son, so she convinced King Eurystheus to create the Twelve Labors, with the intent to kill, humiliate, and exhaust Hercules.

After completing the Twelve Labors, Hercules was granted forgiveness for his past guilt. On his journey home to Thebes, he stopped at Thessaly and helped King Admetus save his wife, Alcestis.

Later, Hercules was attacked by a centaur named Nessus while protecting Deianeria, and Hercules killed Nessus with a poison arrow. However, before he died, Nessus gave Deianeria a love potion that ultimately caused Hercules great pain when she thought he was unfaithful.

Eurystheus was a King in Greek mythology. He was the one who assigned Hercules, also known as Alcides, with the Twelve Labors as a form of punishment for killing his wife and children in a fit of madness. These Twelve Labors were designed by Hera with the intention of killing, humbling, and exhausting Hercules.
